nodes.text: Window 3 is labeled ORIENTATION in peeling block letters. Behind glass: a clerk, a stamp pad, and a stack of thin pamphlets that look pre-handled. A placard lists rules in numbered paragraphs, as if the building is a person with boundaries.

Orientation is a service window, yes. Not—just to be clear—not a promise of comprehension. It’s a distribution point. Paper only.

Do you have an issued TER?

choices.text: ask: Where do I go after Intake?
use: OLEA needs the orientation packet for the closure binder.
leave: Step away from the window.

nodes.text:
Happily. ‘Happily’ as in: it keeps me out of a meeting.

Rule one: Remain within posted lanes. If a lane is unposted, assume it is posted elsewhere.
Rule two: Do not interpret signage. Signage interprets you.
Rule three: If you encounter an unnumbered door, you did not.
Rule four: Any corridor marked SERVICE is not a corridor. It is a condition.

There is an exception for the Map Kiosk routes, because the Map Kiosk is… technically… an official imagination.

Depends what you’re trying to become on paper.

Window 5 for Safety if you want hazard tags. Window 7 for Property if you want your belongings to have an opinion. Window 9 for Complaints if you want a record of your tone.

If you need corridors and a map, there’s a Concourse Service Corridor access point. I’m not directing you there. I’m observing it exists.

No.

We do not have shortcuts. Shortcuts imply the long way was optional, and the long way is where the cameras are calibrated.

We do have… routing efficiencies. Historic. For congestion control. Not for speed.

I can show you a pamphlet. The pamphlet is not a route. The pamphlet is a pamphlet.

Closure binder. Thank you. That’s a real noun. That’s something I can hand to.

Orientation pamphlet, current revision. If it’s not current, it’s still the one we’re allowed to distribute.

You’ll want the stamp for chain-of-custody. Not because anyone will ask. Because if they do ask, they will ask why it’s missing.

The top pamphlet is titled “WELCOME / COMPLIANCE / STAY WITHIN YOUR AUTHORIZED SHAPE.” Several have faint pen marks on the back—quick lines like someone drew a way out and then tried to forget they had hands.

I can do that. I can absolutely do that.

This is informational. If it contradicts posted signage, the signage is correct. If it contradicts itself, it’s a living document.

Do not—and I’m saying this because people get creative—do not add your own annotations and then claim they were provided.

You take the pamphlet. On the back is a rough sketch in ballpoint: a corridor cut-through with a box labeled “MAP KIOSK / CORRIDOR ACCESS,” drawn like someone needed it once and then regretted needing it.

I did not see a sketch.

Ink happens. Ink is not policy.
Remember: if you feel turned around, you are. That is not an emergency unless you write it down as one.
You leave the glass and its rules behind, for now.
